repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Social Crisis Response
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey a satisfactory
            project outcome, likely sustainability, but only modest
            institutional development impacts, supported by satisfactory
            performances by both the Bank and Borrower. Lessons are as
            follows. 1) Lending in the social protection sector - The
            launching of the Unified System of Beneficiary Selection was
            a significant achievement for the Government. However, for
            it to reach its full potential, and ensure objective
            targeting of social safety net programs, the system may need
            to be adapted to address specific requirements of particular
            agencies. The census of beneficiaries also needs to be
            carried out with a transparent sampling plan (to avoid any
            appearance of favoritism of urban/less poor areas over poor
            rural areas). Also of importance are the local technical
            expertise, technical capability, and, the complexity of the
            issue of undocumented families and individuals. 2) Lending
            in a crisis situation - the experience of this operation
            demonstrates that in a crisis situation, Bank lending can
            effectively achieve short-term crisis alleviation, along
            with modest advances on medium policy actions. Flexibility,
            setting realistic expectations and a frank appraisal of
            risks as input to program design (the establishment of loan
            conditions), and, collaboration across sectors and with
            other major donors are critical to success in Bank lending
            under these conditions, although moral hazard remains a risk.

Dominican Republic - Social Crisis Response
            Adjustment Loan Project

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Social Crisis Response
            Adjustment Loan  (SCRAL) Project : release of floating
            tranche "A" based on full compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Dominican Republic Social Crisis
            Response Adjustment Loan (SCRAL) was approved by the Board
            of Directors on February 12, 2004, and became effective on
            March 4, 2004. The loan comprises three single currency
            tranches: a first tranche, and two floating tranches
            henceforth identified as Tranche A and Tranche B. This
            Tranche Release Document (TRD) sets forth a description o f
            the tranche conditions and compliance status of the borrower
            for Tranche A of US$25 million, and concludes that that the
            macroeconomic framework and specific conditions of release
            referred to in Schedule 3 of the Loan Agreement have been satisfied.

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Social Crisis Response
            Adjustment Loan (SCRAL) Project : proposed amendment to the
            loan agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
This report amends the loan agreement
            between the Dominican Republic and the Bank for the Social
            Crisis Response Adjustment Loan (SCRAL) (Loan 7215-DO) in
            order to reflect the government's regulations for
            enrolling individuals in its national health insurance
            program and to reflect its new policies and program's
            for nutrition assistance. In addition it extends the closing
            date in order to provide sufficient time for civil society
            organizations contracted to monitor the government's
            compliance in completing their work.

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Social Crisis Response
            Adjustment Loan: Release of Floating Tranche B Based on Full Compliance

abstracts.cdata!:
The Social Crisis Response Adjustment
            Loan (SCRAL) will help the Dominican Republic cope with the
            current economic and social crisis and to stimulate overdue
            and continuing reforms in both the social and electricity
            sectors. Floating Tranche B is focused on the electricity
            sector and contains three conditions to ensure: (a) supply
            of imported fuel to generate electricity; (b) supply of
            electricity to poor households; and (c) affordability of
            electricity by poor households, by freezing tariffs for
            those consuming less than 200 kilowatt hours per month. In
            view of the overall satisfactory performance and progress
            with the implementation of the program supported by the
            Loan, including the macroeconomic framework and the specific
            conditions of release of the Loan Agreement, the Bank has
            informed the Borrower of the availability for disbursement
            of the floating tranche B of the Loan in the equivalent of
            US$25 million.

5087401.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Urban development,Human development

repnme.cdata!:
Dominican Republic - Social Crisis Response
            Adjustment Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Social Crisis
            Response Adjustment loan Project are to help the Dominican
            Republic cope with the current economic and social crisis
            and to stimulate overdue and continuing reforms in the
            social and electricity sectors. The Dominican Republic in
            early 2003 entered a period of financial crisis,
            precipitated b y a major bank failure, followed b y
            macroeconomic contraction, rapid currency depreciation and
            inflation, increasing incidence of  electricity blackouts as
            power companies could not afford to import fuel, and social
            impacts in the form of substantial real declines in
            household incomes and cutbacks in social services benefiting
            the poor. The poor are most vulnerable to the fall in real
            incomes, as they lack the resources to absorb the higher
            cost of  living. This has led to growing social tensions in
            the form of  protests and violence. The Dominican Republic,
            once one of  the fastest growing economies  in the region,
            now faces an untenable fiscal situation and is at risk of
            further social unrest. The loan would support government
            actions in three areas. First, it would help build the
            response capacities and performance of  social and
            electricity programs through improved targeting of
            resources to the poor, the protection of  key social and
            electricity programs in the 2004 budget, and steps to
            accelerate the inclusion of  the large group of
            undocumented Dominicans. Second, it would support a rapid
            response program in the electricity sector to "keep the
            lights on" during the current period of  social
            tensions. And third, it would provide a stimulus for medium
            term reforms in the social and electricity sectors in such
            areas as targeting mechanisms, program evaluation, health
            reform, and electricity sector sustainability.   The first
            category of  risk is governance, in the context of  the
            upcoming May 2004 Presidential elections, a period that
            could involve the misuse of  social programs for election
            campaign purposes. Linked to that risk is that of  ad hoc
            budget reallocations during the fiscal year, from protected
            to unprotected programs. The second category of risk is that
            of non- compliance with actions for the two floating
            tranches, including maintenance of  a satisfactory
            macroeconomic framework. Finally, there is the risk of  a
            surge in civil disturbances that would undermine consensus
            for social and electricity sector reforms, taking the
            country into deeper crisis. The loan is expected to be
            disbursed during the first six months of  2004 in three tranches.
